USB Connectors

USB-A, USB-B, USB-C, Mini, and Micro variants. The most confusing connector family.

5 connector types documented

Micro USB

USB Micro-B

USB-IF

Max Speed

5 Gbps

Max Power

4.5W

Connector

5 pins, 6.85×1.8mm

Common Uses

Older Android smartphones (pre-2016) E-readers (Kindle) Bluetooth speakers and headphones +5 more

⚠️ USB 3.0 Micro-B is a completely different, wider connector than USB 2.0 Micro-B

Micro USB was mandated by the EU in 2009 as a common charging standard, leading to its widespread adoption on Android phones. It was designed to be more durable than Mini USB with a rated 10,000 insertion cycles. However, its non-reversible design and fragile-feeling connector led to its replacement by USB-C starting around 2015-2016.

Mini USB

USB Mini-B

USB-IF

Max Speed

480 Mbps

Max Power

2.5W

Connector

5 pins, 6.8×3mm

Common Uses

Digital cameras (older models) MP3 players (early 2000s) Older GPS devices (Garmin) +5 more

⚠️ Mini USB is larger and taller than Micro USB - they are not interchangeable

Mini USB was introduced with USB 2.0 in 2000 and was the standard small device connector before Micro USB. It was officially deprecated by USB-IF in 2007 due to durability concerns and the desire for an even smaller connector. However, many devices continued to use it for years, and some niche devices still ship with Mini USB ports today. The PS3 controller's use of Mini USB kept it relevant longer than expected.

USB-A

USB Standard-A

USB-IF

Max Speed

10 Gbps

Max Power

4.5W

Connector

9 pins, 12×4.5mm

Common Uses

Desktop computers Laptops (host ports) Wall chargers +5 more

⚠️ USB 3.x USB-A has 9 pins but is backwards compatible with 4-pin USB 2.0 cables and devices

USB-A is the original USB connector and remains ubiquitous on host devices. While being phased out in favor of USB-C, it will remain common for years due to the massive installed base. The connector was intentionally designed to be non-reversible to ensure proper power delivery orientation, though this is often cited as a design flaw compared to USB-C's reversibility.

USB-B

USB Standard-B

USB-IF

Max Speed

10 Gbps

Max Power

4.5W

Connector

9 pins, 11×10.4mm

Common Uses

Printers Scanners External hard drives (older) +5 more

⚠️ USB 3.0 Type-B has a completely different shape than USB 2.0 Type-B - the top is extended with extra pins

USB-B was designed to prevent users from connecting two host devices together (which USB doesn't support). The distinct shape makes it obvious which end goes where. While being phased out in favor of USB-C, USB-B remains common on printers, audio equipment, and industrial devices where the larger, more robust connector is actually preferred.

USB-C

USB Type-C

USB-IF

Max Speed

80 Gbps

Max Power

240W

Connector

24 pins, 8.4×2.6mm (reversible)

Common Uses

Smartphones (Android) Laptops Tablets +5 more

⚠️ A USB-C cable does NOT guarantee fast charging or data transfer - capabilities depend on the cable's rating

USB-C is the universal connector that isn't quite universal. The same physical connector supports wildly different capabilities depending on the cable, the port, and the protocol negotiated. This is both its greatest strength (one cable for everything) and its biggest source of confusion (which cable for what?).

About USB Connectors

USB (Universal Serial Bus) is the most common connector family, but also the most confusing. The same USB-C connector can support vastly different capabilities depending on the cable and devices involved.

The USB-C Problem

  • USB 2.0: 480 Mbps (same connector)
  • USB 3.2 Gen 2: 10 Gbps (same connector)
  • USB4: 40 Gbps (same connector)
  • Thunderbolt 4: 40 Gbps (same connector)

Power Delivery Confusion

  • Basic USB: 5V @ 0.5A = 2.5W
  • USB BC 1.2: 5V @ 1.5A = 7.5W
  • USB PD 3.0: Up to 100W
  • USB PD 3.1 EPR: Up to 240W
